Mental Anxiety can Hinder your performance in Sports

Performance Anxiety experienced while playing a sport can causes pressure, tension and anxiety. How an athlete copes with tension and anxiety plays a critical part in their success, especially among elite players.

Experiencing stress causes athletes to engage in coping behavior to deal with their anxiety and stress. It also causes athletes to doubt their ability to cope with situations that causes them fear and worry.

Research studies find that stress actually enhances an athlete’s performance; although, if the stress becomes too great their performance will probably deteriorate. Put differently, as stress builds, if the player can remain confident in their ability to control their fear and worry, their performance will improve. But, if their stress becomes too great their ability to cope begins to decline.

How Athletes Are Affected
Sports anxiety powerfully affects athletes’ performances. This holds true regardless of their skill level or work with a mental performance coach.

Studies have found that when athletes interpret stress as helpful than it is far less debilitating than those athletes that were afraid of feeling those feelings.

Gould, Petrchlikoff, and Weinberg (84) have claimed that the best predictor of cognitive anxiety was the number of years of an athlete had experienced anxiety. The longer they had been exposed the less they felt.
Causes of Anxiety

Anxiety in sports performance training comes when the player thinks about anything bad or negative that could happen and this triggers anxiety, according to Craig Sigl, the mental toughness trainer for youth sports athletes. Their bodies actually respond as if they were in immediate physical danger that causes a fight or flight response.
Anxiety in sports usually occurs prior to a big game especially when they are performing before crowds. Additionally, it tends to shows up after a sports athlete experiences some sort of choke or error they usually worry they are going to repeat the big mistake. It also commonly shows up soon after an athlete experiences an injury. They end up playing hesitantly, fearing that they will reinjure themselves.

Effects On The Body
Researchers have found that very competitive state anxiety is definitely higher in amateur sports athletes that play individual sports compared with players in team sports (Simon & Martens, 1977).

When an athlete starts to feel scared and nervous, they start to experience anxiety. The Harvard Mental Health Letter states, "Anxiety normally has the physical symptoms that may include a racing heart, a dry mouth, a shaky voice, shivering, sweating, nausea” and their mind is racing with damaging thoughts.

The feeling connected with fear and anxiety triggers a body to power up its sympathetic nervous system. This takes place when the body releases adrenaline into the blood stream causing the athlete a feeling of the “fight or flight" syndrome.

Answers

The research indicates that it is very critical for athletes to be able to control their anxiety to produce high performances during events. Sigl(1) suggests get a higher perspective if they're having a tough time coping in competitions. This technique allows them to see that their problems are not as big as they thought.

To get the athletes away from their fearful thoughts, they need to ask themselves questions like, "If you don't win your upcoming event, what is the worse thing that will happen? Will you lose all your close friends? Your family? Will you be begging on the streets for food? “ This gets them laughing.

The athletes need to determine how important the game really is in terms of their world. This gets them to weigh the importance they put on their match and how much they've worked themselves up with nothing more than a thought.

In order for the athletes to get over their performance anxiety, they need to accept their challenging emotions including their fear of disappointment and humiliation. They do this by understanding that all emotions are helpful. “They are nothing more than a signal from your body trying to get you to take care of something important” - Craig Sigl1

Predictors of self-confidence identified by researchers are based on their thoughts of preparedness, along with external conditions (Jones, Swain, & Cale, 1990) and being able to deal with difficult emotions.

Self-confidence along with mental coaching has been found to help athletes deal with cognitive anxiety (Hardy, 1996). This means that one of the most influential characteristics that top performers posses is a high level of self-confidence, which provides for a protective component from cognitive anxiety.

Athletes gain confidence, when they feel they can handle difficult situations that come their way. That attitude helps release the FEAR of setbacks, embarrassment or other emotions that come through from losing. Then the anxiety disappears.

Players need to fully understand that they have the power to decide what we think and believe. They can build their mental strength muscle through conditioning with the same consistency and practice that they do with their regular practice and training.
